content: Thanks! That works now. Is there any way to make it so that I don't have to say I.lines every single time?
Andre Hernandez-Espiet (Rutgers) has marked this topic as resolved.
You should just be able to say l \in lines there, as long as the type of l is known

In this line theorem ptoffline {l : set point}(H : l ∈ I.lines): ∃ (p : point), (p ∉ l) := If I remove the I from the hypothesis H then it tells me that it "doesn't know how to synthesize the placeholder". Or is there something that I am misinterpreting?
Andre Hernandez-Espiet (Rutgers) has marked this topic as resolved.
